Name: Requiring the DOE report information regarding alternate learning centers.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of education to report information regarding alternate learning centers

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Education to report demographic and other information concerning middle school students in grades 6-12 who attend Alternate Learning Centers (ALCs) as a result of suspensions from their originating schools lasting five or more days. Such information would include race, ethnicity, gender and languages spoken at home. It would also include data concerning pre-suspension due process, ALC teacher training credentials, and post suspension transitions back to an originating school or to other institutions, such as correctional facilities.

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Chapter 6 of title 21-a of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 21-959.1 to read as follows:\par
\ul\'a7 21-959.1 Annual report on alternate learning centers. a. Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms have the following meanings:\par
Alternate learning center. The term \ldblquote alternate learning center\rdblquote  means a school administered under the authority of the department providing instructional programs for students in grades 6 through 12 who are on superintendent\rquote s suspension. \par
PBIS de-escalation. The term \ldblquote PBIS de-escalation\rdblquote  means positive behavior interventions and supports employed for the purpose of supporting student\rquote s social, emotional and academic success.\par
Restorative justice. The term \ldblquote restorative justice\rdblquote  means an approach to discipline that focuses on repairing harm with an emphasis on learning and community involvement. \par
Superintendent\rquote s suspension. The term \ldblquote superintendent\rquote s suspension\rdblquote  means any period of student suspension that exceeds five days during which time the student attends an alternate learning center.\par
b. Annual reporting. \cf1 By November 1 of each year, the department shall submit to the council and post on its website a report containing the following data for each alternate learning center, with such data calculated as of the end of the immediately preceding school year:\par
\pard\ltrpar\li720\sl480\slmult1\qj 1. The total number of students who attended the center;\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj 2. The number and percentage of total students who attended the center two or more times;\par
3. The number of teachers trained in restorative justice and PBIS de-escalation techniques, respectively;\par
\pard\ltrpar\li720\sl480\slmult1\qj 4. The number and percentage of total students who have attended a center for:\par
(i) Up to 30 days;\par
(ii) Between 31 and 60 days;\par
(iii) Between 61 and 90 days; and\par
(iv) 91 or more days:\par
5. The average ratio of teachers to students;\par
6. The average number of credits accumulated per student;\par
7. For students with an IEP:\par
(i) The number and percentage of total students; and\par
\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj (ii) The number and percentage of students with an IEP whose behavior was a manifestation of their disability and resulted in a suspension;\par
8. The number and percentage of total students who were involved in any court proceedings;\par
9. The number and percentage of total students who were on probation;\par
10. The number and percentage of total students who were discharged to, or previously spent time in the custody of, the department of corrections or administration for children\rquote s services limited secure or non-secure detention.\par
11. The number and percentage of total students who had a hearing before the issuance of a superintendent\rquote s suspension;\par
12. The types of offenses for which students received a superintendent\rquote s suspension; and  \par
13. Whether protocols were followed for transition back to the school from which a student was suspended.\par
c. Demographic information. The data provided pursuant to paragraphs 1 and 2 of subdivision b of this section shall be disaggregated by:\par
1. Grade level;\par
2. Race or ethnicity;\par
3. Gender; and\par
4. For students who are English language learners, primary home language.\par
d. Privacy of student information. No information that is otherwise required to be reported pursuant to this section shall be reported in a manner that would violate any applicable provision of federal, state or local law relating to the privacy of student information or that would interfere with law enforcement investigations or otherwise conflict with the interests of law enforcement. If a category contains between 0 and 9 students, or allows another category to be narrowed to between 0 and 9 students, the number shall be replaced with a symbol.\cf0\par
\ulnone\'a7 2. This local law takes effect 45 days after it becomes law.  \par
